Such is the close of Wyclif⁷s last great work. In it he appears, as in most of the other short tracts written during the latest period of his life⁷ unflinchingly attached to the principles expounded by him before his condemnation at Oxford, and inspired, if possible, with still greater vehemence in his denunciations than before that date, and still more unsparing in his exposure of all that ννειε, or that he considered to be, an abuse.
